cluster.display: In the case of C → C, both the __________ and explanatory variables are categorical.
In the case of C → C, both the response and __________ variables are categorical.
In the case of C → C, both the response and explanatory variables are __________.
The χ<sup>2</sup> test for __________ examines data to see if there is enough evidence to conclude that two categorical variables are related in the population.
The χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence examines data to see if there is enough evidence to conclude that two __________ variables are related in the population.
The χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence examines data to see if there is enough evidence to conclude that two categorical variables are related in the __________.
The __________ hypothesis for a χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence is that there is no relationship between the two categorical variables and that the variables are independent.
The null hypothesis for a χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence is that there is __________ relationship between the two categorical variables and that the variables are independent.
The null hypothesis for a χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence is that there is no relationship between the two categorical variables and that the variables are __________.
By saying two categorical variables are __________, we mean that they exist in equal proportions in the population.
By saying two categorical variables are independent, we mean that they exist in __________ proportions in the population.
By saying two categorical variables are independent, we mean that they exist in equal __________ in the population.
By saying two categorical variables are independent, we mean that they exist in equal proportions in the __________.
The __________ hypothesis for the χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence is that there is a relationship between the two categorical variables and that they are not independent.
The alternative hypothesis for the χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence is that there is a __________ between the two categorical variables and that they are not independent.
The alternative hypothesis for the χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence is that there is a relationship between the two categorical variables and that they are not __________.
In a χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence, we have __________ sets of count data- the observed and the expected counts.
In a χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence, we have two sets of __________ data- the observed and the expected __________s.
In a χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence, we have two sets of count data- the __________ and the expected counts.
In a χ<sup>2</sup> test for independence, we have two sets of count data- the observed and the __________ counts.
We use the two sets of count data to __________ how far away observed data is from the expected counts.
We use the two sets of count data to measure how far away __________ data is from the expected counts.
We use the two sets of count data to measure how far away observed data is from the __________ counts.
A rule of thumb for χ<sup>2</sup> test of independence is that all __________ counts should be greater than 5.
A rule of thumb for χ<sup>2</sup> test of independence is that all expected counts should be __________ than 5.
A rule of thumb for χ<sup>2</sup> test of independence is that all expected counts should be greater than __________.
The __________ the test statistic χ<sup>2</sup>, the more evidence we have against the null hypothesis.
The larger the __________ χ<sup>2</sup>, the more evidence we have against the null hypothesis.
The larger the test statistic χ<sup>2</sup>, the more evidence we have __________ the null hypothesis.
The larger the test statistic χ<sup>2</sup>, the more evidence we have against the __________ hypothesis.
In the Case Q → Q, we are inferring about two __________ variables and looking for a linear relationship.
In the Case Q → Q, we are inferring about two quantitative variables and looking for a __________ relationship.
In a t-test for the __________, the null hypothesis is that there is no linear relationship between variables X and Y.
In a t-test for the slope, the __________ hypothesis is that there is no linear relationship between variables X and Y.
In a t-test for the slope, the null hypothesis is that there is no __________ relationship between variables X and Y.
In a t-test for the __________, the alternative hypothesis is that there is a linear relationship between variables X and Y.
In a t-test for the slope, the __________ hypothesis is that there is a linear relationship between variables X and Y.
In a t-test for the slope, the alternative hypothesis is that there is a __________ relationship between variables X and Y.
In a t-test for the slope, the alternative hypothesis is that there is a linear __________ between variables X and Y.
The __________ coefficient tells us about the strength and direction of a linear relationship.
The correlation __________ tells us about the strength and direction of a linear relationship.
The correlation coefficient tells us about the __________ and direction of a linear relationship.
The correlation coefficient tells us about the strength and __________ of a linear relationship.
The correlation coefficient tells us about the strength and direction of a __________ relationship.
